item.title: Adding terminfo entries to a remote machine
item.description: How many times have you tried to run a terminal program on a remote machine and received an error like: Error opening terminal: xterm-kitty. or a warning like: WARNING: terminal is not fully functional /etc/hosts (press RETURN) You can: export TERM=xterm and see how far it gets you install the terminal emulator package you are using on the remote machine (e.g., sudo apt-get install termite), but this ranges from inconvenient to impossible.

item.title: Copying SSH keys to a remote machine
item.description: Ideally, both source and destination machines have ssh-copy-id available. In that case, just: $ ssh-copy-id -i ~/.ssh/id_rsa user@host If the destination machine does not have ssh-copy-id, you can pipe output from cat through ssh. $ cat ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub | ssh user@host "mkdir -p ~/.ssh; cat >> ~/.ssh/authorized_keys If you already have an entry for the destination machine in your ~/.ssh/config and want to ignore the options specified there, use -o to override, or -F \dev\null to ignore the config entirely.
